The first great vow:

May I, in a future life, attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. At that time, may my own body emit a blazing light illuminating immeasurable, countless, and boundless worlds. Here, those who uphold the eight precepts for a set period of time, for a year or a month, the master Mai says:
Those who do it for a year, meaning within a year, on the sixth day of each month, referring to the eighth, fourteenth, and fifteenth days of both the bright and dark fortnights.

Or three months means that if one cannot observe the six monthly precepts for a year, but can observe the three long months of the year, namely the first, fifth, and ninth months, and the first month of each of the three exclusions, it indicates that one always cultivates goodness throughout the year.
As the Song edition says always cultivating the six monthly precepts and the three long precepts of the year.
The Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom, chapter 13, says Those who observe the eight precepts on fast days, on this day evil ghosts chase people and want to take away people's lives.
In the beginning of the kalpa, sages taught people to observe the fast, but they did not accept the eight precepts. They simply took not eating for one day as the fast.
Later, when the Buddha appeared in the world, he established the eight precepts.
Question:
Which is superior, the five precepts or the eight precepts?
Answer:
For certain reasons, the two precepts are equal, because the time and branches are either more or less.
Question:
If ten recitations of the name can still lead to rebirth, how much more so for one year? Why is it not fixed?
Answer:
Because there is a difference between being courageous and being relaxed.
As the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says, The mind at the time of death is powerful and surpasses a hundred years of practice.
As for being born through spontaneous transformation, the Nirvana Sutra says that the woman of the mango tree was born from the flowers of the tree and is called a moisture-born being.
How can being born from a flower in the Pure Land be called spontaneous transformation?
The teacher Mai says:
Before being conceived, the tree has moist energy.
The lotus flowers in the Pure Land give birth to people through spontaneous transformation.
Second, it can eliminate the obstacles to being born in the defiled lands and joyfully taking rebirth, as the sutra says Some are born in the heavens because of this and so forth.
This also has four aspects: being born in the heavens, as a wheel-turning king, in a noble and superior [rebirth], and in a male body, as can be understood from the text.
